answers: SSRIs [or selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors; prompt on antidepressants]
parts: Name this mental disorder in which repeated intrusive thoughts drive a person to perform repeated behaviors such as counting or hand-washing.
OCD is sometimes treated with this specific class of drugs, whose brand names include Lexapro, Prozac, and Zoloft.

The related but contentious obsessive-compulsive personality disorder is placed in this cluster of "anxious" disorders alongside avoidant and dependent personality disorders. In the common naming scheme, this cluster is contrasted with the "odd" and "dramatic" clusters.

answers: Foucault pendulum [or Foucault's pendulum; prompt on pendulum]
Larmor precession [prompt on partial, prompt on Larmor frequency]
parts: Name this system. Using a rotating reference frame, it can be shown that this system gains a geometric phase factor, disrupting the underlying planar motion with frequency 'root g over l'.

The Foucault (foo-COH) pendulum has a period of one day over this function of latitude. Pendulums are modeled as simple harmonic oscillators under the approximation that this function of theta equals theta for small angles.
The trick of moving to a rotating reference frame can also be used to derive this phenomenon with frequency equal to minus the gyromagnetic ratio times magnetic field strength.

answers: The Wretched of the Earth [or Les Damnés de la Terre]
parts: Name this novel in which Tambu enters a missionary school run by her uncle Babamukuru after her brother Nhamo's death.

Tsitsi Dangarembga (tuh-SIT-see dan-gar-EMB-gah) set her novel Nervous Conditions in this country home to NoViolet Bulawayo. Authors from this country have satirized corruption by its Prime Minister Robert Mugabe.
The title of Nervous Conditions comes from Jean-Paul Sartre's introduction to this Frantz Fanon book which analyzes the dehumanizing effects of colonization and the revolt of the lumpenproletariat.

answers: meatpacking industry [or beef or pork industry; or slaughterhouses; prompt on the food industry]
refrigerated train cars [or refrigeration inside railroad cars; prompt on partial answers]
parts: Name this industry accused of sending "embalmed" products to soldiers in the Spanish-American War.

This Ohio city, named indirectly for a Roman dictator, was nicknamed "Porkopolis" after Elisha Mills established the first large-scale pork-packing plant here in 1818. Macedonian immigrants to this city invented a form of chili popularized by the Skyline chain.

Joel Tiffany and Andrew Chase secured separate patents after modifying William Davis's original design for this invention, which more than doubled the income of the Swift and Armour meatpacking companies.

answers: the Armenian Genocide [or the Armenian Holocaust or Medz Yeghern; prompt on genocide; do not accept or prompt on "Holocaust" alone]
Willem de Kooning (That is his Woman series)
parts: Name this event which may have caused an artist to leave his mother's hands unfinished in his painting The Artist and his Mother.

A copy of Arshile (ahr-sheel) Gorky's The Artist and his Mother is held at the Whitney, but the version with terracotta patterning is displayed in this city's National Gallery. The Smithsonian Institute is found in this city.

After his mother died, Gorky moved to America and lived with this artist, the subject of his Portrait of Master Bill. This artist included a piece modeled on the Venus of Willendorf and a collage using a cutout from a cigarette ad in one series.

answers: Barbara Ehrenreich (The last book described is Nickel and Dimed)
parts: Name this thinker who authored Death of a Yuppie Dream with her husband John. Her book Bait and Switch followed up on a book analyzing effects of the 1996 welfare reform bill through the author’s experiences in Florida, Maine and Minnesota.
In one chapter of Nickel and Dimed, Barbara Ehrenreich takes a low-wage job at a Minnesota store of this Arkansas-based company. This retailer is the world's largest company by revenue.
Barbara Ehrenreich discusses her cancer survivorship in a 2009 book critical of this genre of writing. Dale Carnegie and Stephen R. Covey are best known for books in this genre.

answers: Baker's yeast [or Saccharomyces or Saccharomyces cerevisiae]
ubiquitin [accept split ubiquitin two-hybrid assay or similar answers]
sugars [or carbohydrates; accept monosaccharides or disaccharides]
parts: Name this model organism in which that two-hybrid assay is most commonly performed.

Normal two-hybrid assays don't work on membrane proteins, as the fused transcription factor can't enter the nucleus. For those proteins, a variant in which this protein is "split" into Cub and Nub domains is used instead.

The most common transcription factor used in 2-hybrid assays, GAL4, codes enzymes that aid in metabolizing one of these compounds, galactose. A reporter gene for two-hybrid assays breaks down lactose, another of these compounds.

answers: Pan Tadeusz (pahn TAH-day-oosh) [or Master Thaddeus] (by Adam Mickiewicz)
judges [accept magistrates] (The play is Brecht’s The Caucasian Chalk Circle)
parts: Name this literary movement associated with the "Three Bards" of Polish poetry. Their interest in the natural world was partly inspired by this movement's British members like Byron and Wordsworth.
In this Polish romantic poem, the title character falls in love with Zosia, a member of a rival family. It somewhat counterintuitively opens "O Lithuania, my homeland!"
The orphan Tadeusz is raised by his uncle Soplica, who has this profession. In a play, a man with this profession declares Grusha and not the Governor's Wife to be Michael's true mother.

answers: Behistun Inscription [accept the Bisutun Inscription; or the Bisotun Inscription; or the Bagastana Inscription; or the Bisitun Inscription]
parts: Give this name of Cambyses II's younger brother. Darius the Great prevented a Magian named Gaumata from taking the Persian throne by claiming that he was a "false" person with [this name].

An image of the false Smerdis kneeling before Darius the Great can be found on this rock inscription in Kermanshah Province. Henry Rawlinson was the first to translate the writing on this rock relief.

In The Histories, this historian argued that Darius came to power with the help of six other conspirators, including Megabyzus and Hydarnes, who overthrew Gaumata. This Greek historian is considered to be the "father of history."

answers: Pax [prompt on Peace; prompt on Ara Pacis]
parts: Name these objects also associated with gods like Plutus (ploo-tuss), the god of wealth.
Eirene was depicted bestowing clothing and garlands on various mythological women, including this wife of Epimetheus (eh-pi-mee-thee-us) who opens a jar releasing all evils into the world.

An altar on the Campus Martius (kam-poos mar-tee-oos) and a new temple known as this goddess's forum were built by Augustus in honor of this Roman equivalent of Eirene, who was depicted as bringing children and crops during a period instituted by Augustus.

answers: Waldensians [or Waldenses; or Vallenses; or Valdesi; or Vaudois]
parts: Name this office first held by a Saint Augustine who wasn't from Hippo. It was also held by the martyred Thomas à Becket.

Archbishop Thomas Arundel is largely known as an opponent of this movement, whose members were depicted on misericords as foxes in priestly garb preaching to geese. They were founded by John Wycliffe.

The Lollards may have gotten their name from a member of this other proto-Protesant group named Lolhard. A Milton sonnet commemorates the Piedmontese Easter, in which these advocates of voluntary poverty were massacred.

answers: Vietnamese [or Vietnamese-American] (Those authors are Ocean Vuong and Viet Thanh Nguyen.)
film [or movie or cinema or motion picture]
Gertrude Stein and Alice B(abette) Toklas [accept in either order; prompt on partial answers] (The second sentence refers to The Autobiography of Alice B. Toklas)
parts: Name this ethnicity of the author of On Earth We're Briefly Gorgeous. An author of this ethnicity wrote a novel in the form of a spy's confession after his capture, titled The Sympathizer.
The protagonist of The Sympathizer consults for a work in this medium called The Hamlet, which is a reference to a work in this medium, Francis Ford Coppola's Apocalypse Now.

The Vietnamese cook Binh works at the home of these two real-life people in Monique Truong's novel The Book of Salt. One of these two people imagines writing The Wives of Geniuses I Have Sat With before writing about their time with the other person.

answers: Titan Symphony [accept but do NOT otherwise reveal Symphony No. 1 by Gustav Mahler or Gustav Mahler's First Symphony]
parts: Name this symphony composed several years after Rott's death. This symphony's Blumine (bloo-MEEN) movement was removed after its first edition.

Hans Rott was called "a musician of genius" by this composer of the Titan Symphony who studied with him in Vienna. This composer incorporated lieder from his Des Knaben Wunderhorn in symphonies like Resurrection.

Despite the sonic similarity to Rott's scherzo, the second movement of the Titan Symphony is actually one of these German dances. Mahler later used this dance in the second movement of his Ninth Symphony.

answers: solvated electrons [or e- (e-minus); prompt on electrides]
electron-withdrawing groups [or EWG; accept deactivating groups]
parts: Name these particles, which are the smallest possible anions. The energy to release one of these particles is the ionization energy.

This scientist found that exposing benzene derivatives to solvated electrons, typically derived from sodium, would produce the corresponding cyclohexadienes while developing the first synthesis of an androgen steroid.

Substituting a group with this property to an arene allows the Birch reduction to target the ipso and para position rather than the ortho and meta. In general groups with this property have a negative mesomeric effect.

answers: land reclamation [accept descriptive answers that convey taking underwater land and making it useable land]
Marshall Plan [or the European Recovery Program; or ERP]
parts: Name this type of campaign exemplified by the Zuiderzee Works project. The district of Fontvieille in Monaco, as well as much of the rest of the country, was the subject of a project of this type.

During the Renaissance, the Dutch built polders that used these buildings to pump water into canals called bosoms. Fantails are used in these types of buildings to help them account for environmental conditions.
The Delta Works were funded by the discovery of natural gas in Dutch waters and this program. This program was designed to provide American aid to Europe after World War II.
Name this 18th-century thinker, who proposed that mankind arose from a "bestial age" in his work The New Science.
Vico's The New Science proposes a "cyclical" form of this concept. Francis Fukuyama analyzed the "last man" in a book titled for the "end of" this concept.

Vico was one of the main thinkers that Isaiah Berlin identified as part of the Counter-Enlightenment, alongside Johann Gottfried Herder and this other thinker, who was Herder's mentor. This thinker wrote the essay Socratic Memorabilia.

answers: hair [accept Amarantha's hair; accept "Song to Amarantha, that she would Dishevel her Hair"]
parts: Name this thing which belongs to Amarantha. This title thing is described as a "spicy nest" in a poem which ends, "our very sorrows weep, / That joys so ripe, so little keep."

Amarantha's hair was praised by Richard Lovelace, who wrote about lying tangled in Althea's hair in a poem set in one of these places. That poem ends, "Stone Walls do not [one of these places] make, / Nor Iron bars a Cage."

Lovelace tells Amarantha to "shake your head and scatter" her hair like this thing. At the end of "To His Coy Mistress," the speaker says, "we cannot make [this thing] / Stand still, yet we will make him run."

answers: left padding a string [accept descriptions that indicate making a string the right length or adding empty spaces to a string; accept left-pad]
parts: Describe this task of a simple 11-line long package by Azer Koçulu that, upon its deletion, caused the compiler Babel and any project using it to fail.

The deletion of left-pad and subsequent fallout led to scrutiny over the practices of npm, the default package manager for this server-side Javascript library. It is named for a generic term for any device that sends data on a network.
In 2018, another popular npm dependency, event-stream, was updated with malicious code to steal account details from people with this commodity, a cryptocurrency first described by Satoshi Nakamoto.

answers: white buffaloes [accept White Buffalo Calf Woman; accept White Buffalo Maiden; prompt on buffalo]
parts: Name these structures used for purification rituals. In the Lakota rite of Inipi (in-ip-ee), the door to one of these structures is opened four times.

The door is opened four times in reference to the four ages of a prophet who taught the Lakota the Seven Sacred Rites; that prophet is named after these rare, sacred animals in Plains Indian Tradition.

The White Buffalo Calf Woman gave the Lakota a sacred one of these objects to use in the Seven Sacred Rites. Kinnikinnick (ki-nee-ki-nuhk) is smoked in these objects, which may also be used to seal a peace treaty.

answers: calligraphy [accept word forms like calligraphic writing; prompt on writing alone]
parts: This is the larger of two islands on which a panel called the kepala is created by sewing together rows of triangles with golden thread on sarongs. Wayang (WHY-ahng) shadow puppet performances often accompanied by kendhang (kend-AHNG) drums originated on this island.

Sarongs are often dyed using this process in which a design is covered in melted wax so it doesn't absorb vegetable oil. Oral tradition passed down in Indonesia has taught how to use pen-like cantings (chan-TING) to create designs that may be printed with a copper tool called a cap.
Batik designs were influenced by this Islamic art form which may be written in Kufic (KOO-fick) or Naskh script with pen and ink.

answers: azo compounds [accept azo dyes or azo pigments]
substitution reactions [accept electrophilic aromatic substitution; prompt on EAS]
parts: Name this class of compounds which have a central nitrogen-nitrogen double bond that is often bound to aryl (AIR-il) groups. Radical initiators like AIBN are examples of these compounds.
Azo compounds are synthesized by a namesake coupling, an example of the electrophilic aromatic variant of this reaction type. Reactions of this type replace one functional group with another.
An alternative route to azo compounds is oxidizing derivatives of this molecule with formula N2H4. The harsh Wolff-Kishner reduction uses this molecule to remove carbonyls (carbon-EELZ).
